questions.text: Interstitial lung disease (ILD) is an umbrella term used for a large group of diseases that cause scarring (fibrosis) of the lungs. The scarring causes lung stiffness, making breathing difficult and getting oxygen to the bloodstream difficult. Lung damage from ILDs is often irreversible and gets worse over time. Which of the following cytokine is most potent and fibrogenic?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

TGF beta All white blood cell lineages produce TGF Beta proteins . TGF-β is upregulated and activated in fibrotic diseases and modulates fibroblast phenotype and function, inducing myofibroblast transdifferentiation while promoting matrix preservation. TGF Beta is the most critical fibrogenic cytokine.

questions.text: A 76-year-old male suffers from a restrictive lung condition, which can be explained as a clinicopathologic syndrome marked by progressive interstitial pulmonary fibrosis and respiratory failure. HRCT shows Bilateral subpleural reticular changes most prominent in lower, posterior lung zones. It is the most common type of interstitial lung disease. Identify the condition?'
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis Chronic interstitial lung diseases, or we can call them idiopathic interstitial pneumonia, are divided into various subtypes. The most common of them is idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a clinicopathologic syndrome marked by progressive interstitial pulmonary fibrosis and respiratory failure. IPF can lead to the honeycombing of the Lungs. HRCT finding showing reticular opacities at lung base = IPF is the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presented with Symptoms including tightening of the skin, joint pain, exaggerated response to cold, and the following finding - Identify the most commonly associated lung finding with this condition.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nonspecific interstitial fibrosis Joint pain - arthritis Exaggerated response to cold - Raynaud's phenomenon Therefore, it must be a connective tissue disorder , and the diagnosis can be systemic sclerosis. The image of scleroderma confirms the patient to be having sclerosis. The most common lung finding in a sclerosis patient is NSIP, whereas the most common lung finding in a patient of Rheumatoid Arthritis is UIP. Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) is associated with diffuse interstitial fibrosis (nonspecific interstitial pattern more common than usual) and pleural involvement.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presented to OPD with a subacute flu-like illness, cough, dyspnea, fever, and fatigue. Inspiratory rales are present on examination, and patients are noted to have restrictive lung deficits on pulmonary function testing with hypoxemia. The patient is suffering from polymyositis. Radiological imaging findings include patchy, sometimes migratory, subpleural consolidative opacities, often with associated ground-glass opacities. The underlying lung architecture is normal. There is no interstitial fibrosis or honeycomb lung. Histologically, it shows polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue ‘Masson bodies’ within alveolar ducts, alveoli, and often bronchioles. What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia It is a Subacute flu-like illness. Inspiratory rales and restrictive pattern - ILD Polymyositis - connective tissue disorder - looking at it, we can think of NSIP, or COP ( cryptogenic organizing pneumonia) Radiology - migratory opacity - subpleural - ground glass , lung architecture standard, no honeycombing - NSIP is less likely because it has diffuse symmetric bilateral ground glass opacities and can spare subpleural area. Masson bodies present - diagnosis of COP can be confirmed.

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis does not present with the above features Option: D. questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented to opd with dyspnea on exertion and a persistent dry cough for two years. The patient had a 75-pack-year history of smoking. A pulmonary function test revealed restrictive lung pathology, and the patient was suspected of having smoking-associated interstitial lung disease. Which of the following is the least possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pulmonary lymphangiomyomatosis Smoking-related diseases can be grouped into obstructive diseases (emphysema and chronic bronchitis, already discussed) and restrictive or interstitial diseases. A majority of individuals with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis are smokers. Desquamative interstitial pneumonia and respiratory bronchiolitis–associated interstitial lung disease are two other smoking-associated interstitial lung diseases worthy of brief mention.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Desquamative Interstitial Pneumonia is characterized by extensive collections of macrophages in the airspaces of a current or former smoker. The macrophages were initially thought to be desquamated pneumocytes—thus the misnomer “ desquamative interstitial pneumonia. ” The most striking finding is the accumulation of many macrophages with abundant cytoplasm containing dusty brown pigment (smokers’ macrophages) in the airspaces. Option: B. Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare disease characterized by focal collections of Langerhans cells (often accompanied by eosinophils). More than 90% of affected patients are relatively young adult smokers or ex-smokers; among smokers, about half improve after smoking cessation. Option: D. Respiratory bronchiolitis–associated interstitial lung disease is marked by chronic inflammation and peribronchiolar fibrosis. It is a typical histologic lesion in cigarette smokers.

Extraedge:

Respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts, and peribronchiolar spaces contain aggregates of dusty brown macrophages (smokers’ macrophages) similar to those seen in desquamative interstitial pneumonia. Langerhans cell histiocytosis occurs in Young men ILD with pneumothorax can be the presentation. smoking-related ILDs, including respiratory bronchiolitis with interstitial lung disease (RB-ILD) and DIP, are frequently subclassified with the IIPs, these disorders along with PLCH, an ILD with unique clinical, imaging, and histopathologic manifestations) are commonly felt to result from active or prior tobacco smoke exposure. These disorders predominantly occur in active and, in many cases, heavy smokers who are typically between 40 and 50. Dyspnea and cough are relatively common and symptomatic in those diagnosed with RB-ILD or DIP.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with progressively worsening dyspnea and non-productive cough for one year. He was a sugar cane plantation worker and had prior recurrent respiratory infections. A physical exam revealed cyanosis and bilateral fine rales. Chest computed tomography showed a diffuse crazy paving pattern.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis Keywords - 30-year-old male non-productive cough sugar cane plantation worker with recurrent respiratory infections, cyanosis, and bilateral fine rales diffuse crazy paving pattern thick whitish proteinaceous protein eosinophilic PAS-positive macrophage.

Highyeild:

These features point toward diagnosing “ pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. “ Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP) is a rare disease caused by defects in pulmonary macrophage function due to deficient granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) signaling, which results in the accumulation of surfactant in the intra-alveola r and bronchiolar spaces. PAP is associated with a crazy paving appearance. bilateral patchy a symmetric pulmonary opacifications. the disease is characterized by the accumulation of intra-alveolar precipitates containing surfactant proteins , causing focal-to-confluent consolidation of large areas of the lungs with minimal inflammatory reaction. a marked increase in the size and weight of the lung. The alveolar precipitate is pink, homogeneous, and periodic acid–Schiff–positive macrophages. Progressive dyspnea, cyanosis, and respiratory insufficiency may occur. Whole-lung lavage is the standard of care.

NSIP - it is related to connective tissue disease, which also occurs in older patients.
